BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: During the night danger level 4 (high) will be reached in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Up to 1800 m rain will fall until Friday. A lot of new snow at high altitude.
As a consequence of the precipitation more dry and moist avalanches are possible, but they can be large, especially on very steep slopes, and at the base of rock walls and at high altitude, in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation in particular. In the typical avalanche paths here the avalanches can in isolated cases reach the bare valleys.
As the snowfall level drops only isolated ground avalanches are possible.
The conditions are critical for backcountry touring. The fresh snow and the wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above approximately 2200 m. At high altitude the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 40 cm of snow has fallen since Tuesday above approximately 2600 m. 30 to 40 cm of snow will fall in the next few hours above approximately 2300 m. The southeasterly wind has transported the new snow.
The old snowpack is well consolidated. New snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
The weather conditions gave rise to moistening of the snowpack also at intermediate and high altitudes.
In particular at intermediate and high altitudes there is still a very large amount of snow. Below approximately 2000 m hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Gradual decrease in avalanche danger as the precipitation eases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wet snow represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the precipitation the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase. The avalanches can release the moist old snow as well and can reach as far as low altitudes. This applies in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. The fresh snow and the wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant,. Up to 2200 m rain has fallen over a wide area. As the moisture increases more large moist and wet avalanches are to be expected, in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. Wet avalanches can reach a long way in particular in steep gullies. The conditions are precarious for backcountry touring and snowshoe hiking.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 70 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since yesterday above approximately 2700 m. The southeasterly wind has transported some snow.
The wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack. Intensive rain to intermediate altitudes: The weather conditions gave rise to significant moistening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wet snow represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the precipitation the size of the avalanche prone locations will increase. In particular on very steep slopes the avalanches can release the moist old snow as well and reach quite a large size. This applies in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. The fresh snow and the sometimes large wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. Above approximately 2500 m in some localities danger level 4 (high) will be reached. As the moisture increases medium-sized and large moist and wet avalanches are to be expected, especially at low and intermediate altitudes. Wet avalanches can reach a long way in particular in steep gullies. Ski touring and snowshoe hiking call for experience and a certain restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 60 cm of snow has fallen since yesterday above approximately 2700 m. The southeasterly wind has transported some snow.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack. The weather conditions gave rise to significant moistening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wet snow represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the snowfall the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase. The avalanches can release the moist old snow as well and reach large size. This applies in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. The fresh snow and the wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant,. Up to 2500 m rain has fallen. Medium-sized and large moist and wet avalanches are to be expected. This applies at low and intermediate altitudes. Wet avalanches can reach a long way in particular in steep gullies. Ski touring and snowshoe hiking call for experience and a certain restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow has fallen since yesterday above approximately 2700 m. The southeasterly wind will transport the snow.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack. Rain to intermediate altitudes: The weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of the precipitation there will be a gradual increase in the danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wet snow represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Up to 1800 m rain will fall until Friday. New snow at intermediate altitudes.
As a consequence of the precipitation more dry and moist avalanches are possible, but they can be large in isolated cases, especially on very steep slopes, and at the base of rock walls and at high altitude, in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation in particular along the border with France. The danger exists in particular in alpine snow sports terrain.

Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger. The fresh snow and the wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above approximately 2200 m. At high altitude the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and the danger is greater.
As a consequence of the moderate northwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form in the evening.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 15 cm of snow has fallen since Tuesday above approximately 2600 m. 20 to 30 cm of snow will fall in the next few hours above approximately 2300 m. The southeasterly wind has transported the new snow.
The old snowpack is well consolidated. New snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
The weather conditions gave rise to moistening of the snowpack also at intermediate and high altitudes. In particular here there is still a very large amount of snow.
Below approximately 2000 m hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of new snow and a moderate wind from northwesterly directions, wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as at high altitude.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wet snow represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Medium-sized and large moist and wet avalanches are to be expected. This applies especially at low and intermediate altitudes. As before wet avalanches can reach a long way in steep gullies. In particular on very steep slopes the avalanches can release the moist old snow as well and reach quite a large size, in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. The fresh snow and the sometimes large wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, but less in some localities, has fallen since yesterday above approximately 2700 m. The southeasterly wind will transport the snow.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack. Intensive rain to intermediate altitudes: The weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
As a consequence of the precipitation there will be an increase in the avalanche danger.
The conditions are unfavourable for backcountry touring.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In all aspects wet loose snow avalanches are possible. Gliding avalanches are also to be expected.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can be released by small loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Above approximately 2000 m snow will fall over a wide area. The wind slabs of the last few days will be covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise. In many cases wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. This applies in particular on shady slopes.
The weather conditions will give rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area.
Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be cloudy. Over a wide area precipitation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
High altitudes and the high Alpine regions: Increase in danger of dry avalanches as a consequence of new snow and strong wind. The fresh wind slabs are in isolated cases prone to triggering on west to north to east facing aspects. Avalanches can reach medium size in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.

As a consequence of the precipitation wet and gliding avalanches are possible, especially below approximately 2600 m. In very isolated cases avalanches can release the saturated snowpack and reach a dangerous size.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: High Alpine regions: In some localities up to 15 cm of snow will fall. As a consequence of a sometimes strong wind from southerly directions, wind slabs will form in particular in the vicinity of peaks. The rain will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Fresh wind slabs in the high Alpine regions. Decrease in danger of wet avalanches as the temperature drops.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Up to 1800 m rain will fall until Friday. A lot of new snow at high altitude.
As a consequence of the precipitation more dry and moist avalanches are possible, but they can be large, especially on very steep slopes, and at the base of rock walls and at high altitude, in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation in particular. In the typical avalanche paths here the avalanches can in isolated cases reach the bare valleys.
As the snowfall level drops only isolated ground avalanches are possible.
The conditions are critical for backcountry touring. The fresh snow and the wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above approximately 1900 m. At high altitude the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow has fallen since yesterday above approximately 2300 m. The southeasterly wind has transported some snow.
The wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack. Intensive rain to intermediate altitudes: The weather conditions gave rise to significant moistening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Increase in danger of dry avalanches as a consequence of the precipitation. Avalanches can reach medium size in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation. This applies in particular on wind-loaded slopes. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular on steep slopes above approximately 2500 m.
As a consequence of the rain wet and gliding avalanches are possible as the day progresses, especially below approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some regions up to 30 cm of snow will fall above approximately 2500 m. As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes strong wind, wind slabs will form in particular in the vicinity of peaks. The rain will give rise to increasing and thorough wetting of the snowpack below approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be cloudy. Further decrease in danger of wet avalanches as the temperature drops.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the precipitation individual moist and wet avalanches are possible, but they will be mostly small. The avalanches can occur naturally as well. The avalanche prone locations are to be found especially in extremely steep terrain at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: At intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying. At high altitude only a little snow is lying. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations. The rain will give rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack. As a consequence of falling temperatures and snowfall above approximately 2200 m the snowpack will consolidate in the evening.
